original_title: Sri Lanka stocks close up, driven by capital goods, banks
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – The Colombo Stock Exchange closed up on Tuesday following a cooling off, brokers said.
The All Share Price Index was up 1.30 percent, or 263.98 points, at 20,619; while the S&P SL20 was up 1.19 percent, or 69.27 points, at 5,868.
“There are bound to be a few corrections here and there, but overall there is nothing too negative impacting the market,” Shadini Silva, Co-Head of Research at Softlogic Stockbrokers, said.
“There’s not much alternative to the stock market for investors at the moment.”
Confidence in banks was driving the market in the day, Silva said, with almost all banking stocks closing up, recovering from the previous day.

The ASPI was pushed up by Commercial Bank (up 3.75 rupees at 186.50), Sampath Bank (up 2.75 rupees at 139.75), Hatton National Bank (up 4.75 rupees at 384.75), Aitken Spence (up 5.75 rupees at 155.75), and DFCC Bank (up 3.25 rupees at 155).
Sierra Cables was actively traded in the day (Rs712mn); the stock closed up 3.80 rupees at 31.60.
Capital Goods stocks contributed the most to the day’s turnover.
Top turnover generators were Sierra Cables, R I L Property, L V L Energy Fund, Hemas Holdings, and Prime Lands Residencies.

Top foreign buying was seen in Digital Mobility Solutions (PickMe) (up 1.75 rupees at 128), People’s Leasing and Finance (up 10 cents at 23.20 rupees), Sierra Cables (up 3.80 rupees at 31.60), R I L Property (up 2.30 rupees at 35), Pan Asia Banking Corporation (up 1 rupee at 58) and Seylan Bank (up 1.50 rupees at 97).

Top foreign selling was seen in Chevron Lubricants (up 75 cents at 172.75 rupees), Hemas Holdings (up 40 cents at 30.30 rupees), Access Engineering (up 2 rupees at 59.20), Nations Trust Bank (up 5.75 rupees at 269.25), Teejay Lanka (up 50 cents at 43.40 rupees), and Tokyo Cement (up 70 cents at 84 rupees).
Crossings were seen on Chevron Lubricants, Hemas Holdings, Central Finance Company, Aitken Spence, Hayleys, LB Finance, Sampath Bank, Singer, Alumex, and Lankem Developments. (Colombo/Sep16/2025)
